body: For the last five years, Cobble Hill has prospered with New York City, its stately brownstones drawing young couples to its quiet streets just blocks from downtown Brooklyn. This week, the Giuliani administration said that one of its landmarked blocks would be home to a new homeless shelter. In Cobble Hill, the reaction was furious. Residents and
title: Cobble Hill Denounces Plan for a Homeless Shelter

body: After a day of mixed signals, officials in the Giuliani administration said last night that they were standing by their plan to evict a state-run psychiatric center from a city-owned building in Brooklyn and open a homeless shelter there. The officials said they would help the state find a new location for the center before forcing it out of the
title: Mayor Sticks to Shelter Plan Aimed at Councilman

body: The Giuliani administration announced yesterday that it intended to open a new homeless shelter in a Brooklyn neighborhood represented by a City Council member who had sponsored legislation to regulate such shelters. The Council passed the bill over the heated objection of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who had warned that he would open new shelters in
title: Giuliani Escalates Fight With Council on Homeless

body: In a city where people are known to brawl over parking spots, it is little wonder that each year there is a fresh crop of disputes over New York's highly coveted open spaces. This year was no exception, yielding tugs of war that pitted bike riders against bird-watchers, bird-watchers against anglers, and equestrians against the police. In some of
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: THE YEAR'S TURF WARS; Infighting for a Bit of the Outdoors

body: IN parts of Brooklyn these days, even the dullest community board meeting can count on coverage by half a dozen local newspapers. The opening of a supermarket might draw a phalanx of photographers. These papers have their bigger stories, too. ''Rats! Super Vermin Are Taking Over the Streets'' shouted a recent cover of The Brooklyn Graphic. The
title: NEW YORKERS & CO.; In Brooklyn, There's No Stopping the Presses

author: William R. Everdell teaches history at St. Ann's School in Brooklyn and is the author of ''The First Moderns.''

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: COBBLE HILL; What's In A Name? A Contest

title: Habitats / Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn; An Apartment Seeker Becomes a Landlord

body: IT'S classic. It's irresistible. And it's a killer. Two bites into the standard pecan pie, and even dessert-toughened Yankees raised on chocolate decadence cake, tiramisu and creme brulee know that they're in deep trouble. This pie is sweeter than a Shirley Temple film festival, more cloying than a Barbara Walters interview. Like Rhine maidens
title: Too Sweet to Eat? A Proposal for the Pie

title: More Than Just a Movie House; A Magnet for Brooklyn's Young Is in Place, but Will It Work?

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD: UPPER EAST SIDE; Jewish Holiday Stories With Puppets and Shtick

body: THE potato ricer has survived into the age of the food processor. And it has the starch content of the potato to thank. The food processor's blade slices open too many of its starchy cells, and what you end up with is not a silky potato puree, but a sticky, gluey, unpleasant mess. So the potato ricer remains the only way to get a perfectly smooth
title: TEST KITCHEN; And Now to the Hardware: A Ricer, of Course, but Which?

body: THE SETTING -- The 10,500 Pop-Tarts gave off a strong factory-made strawberry scent as they were laid side by side on tables in the marble and neon entrance to the Theater at Madison Square Garden Tuesday morning. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN -- BUZZ; Wanted: One Very Large Toaster

body: To the Editor: Being of Sicilian extraction, I read with great interest Cara De Silva's account of the socca in Nice (''The Chickpea's Shining Moment,'' July 26). title: Socca in Brooklyn

title: Snack Prices Vary Widely at Movie Theaters, City Says

body: The muck-ridden Gowanus Canal, which dates to the 19th century and runs through Cobble Hill, Park Slope and Carroll Gardens, has been so smelly that for decades it's been compared to the River Styx, the mythological river of the dead. Many people who live nearby have all but given up hope of seeing something done about the odor. But now the city is
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GOWANUS; Dredging Up A Revived Waterway

body: Parents are forever trying to teach their children that sharing toys is good. But such generosity can also yield health benefits. So a Cobble Hill couple are founding one of the region's few toy libraries, to help ill infants who are economically disadvantaged. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CROWN HEIGHTS; A Library for Toy Therapy

title: In 'Rent' 1998, the Renters Sing the Blues

body: Passing Tea and Scones In a Garden in Brooklyn Tea in the garden is an inviting notion on a balmy afternoon in late spring. And the new, umbrella-shaded garden at Sweet Melissa in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, fulfills the fantasy. Sweet Melissa, a pastry shop and cafe that opened in April at 276 Court Street (Butler Street), serves tea from 1:30 to 5:30
title: Food Stuff

body: Roy Fidel was talking to a few friends late Sunday night in Carroll Park, a small patch of trees and lawns in a brownstone-lined section of Brooklyn, when a green car pulled up and a man with a gun got out. The man pointed his pistol at Mr. Fidel's friends, who were sitting on a park bench, and ordered them to ''scatter like cockroaches,'' said
title: Gunman Fatally Shoots Man in a Brooklyn Park

body: Sidewalk Slabs Q. Wandering around the city, I occasionally come upon stretches of 19th-century sidewalk made from huge slabs of bluestone or granite. title: F.Y.I.

body: ANNA MARIE and JOSEPH ZACCARDO are recent first-time home owners in the Rosebank section of Staten Island, near the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. But while most first-time owners come to that status as young adults, the Zaccardos have gotten there in their 60's, and more by accident than design. Mrs. Zaccardo, now 64, was 17 when she moved with her
title: PERSPECTIVES; A Push Beyond Loans Lifts Novices to Ownership

body: A Brooklyn teen-ager was struck on the head and injured yesterday by bricks falling from the facade of a building in the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn. The accident occurred at 5:30 P.M. as the teen-ager, Robert Ganic, was standing in front of 200 Clinton Street at Atlantic Avenue, said Lieut. Richard Pagona, a spokesman for the Fire Department.
title: Teen-Ager Is Hit on Head by Falling Bricks

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: COBBLE HILL; Nurses' Give-Backs at Issue

body: Todd Neuhaus, an advertising executive, and his wife, Christina, didn't want much. They wanted to rent a Manhattan apartment for less than $3,000 with a bedroom for themselves and one for their two boys. They wanted it to be near good public schools, because private school was beyond their means. Most of all, the Neuhauses wanted to believe it
title: For Middle Class, New York Shrinks as Home Prices Soar

title: Manhattan Strength Lifts All Boroughs

body: For more than 35 years, as Cobble Hill, Park Slope, and other Brooklyn neighborhoods of brownstone and old brick have revived, a mile-long corridor through the middle of the area has continued to crumble, collect weeds and drive people away. The dead zone extends for several blocks along the banks of the malodorous Gowanus Canal, a dead-end
title: Flushing Out the Foul And the Frustration; A New Vista for a Dead-End Canal

body: LAUREN GLANT gazed at the contents of a small plastic container as if they were diamonds. ''Eggshells,'' she said proudly. Very old eggshells, she said, mixed with a little bit of ash, that she had helped unearth from a cistern in her backyard at 35 Wyckoff Avenue in the Boerum Hill section of Brooklyn. Chances are they landed there sometime in the
title: Habitats/35 Wyckoff Avenue, Boerum Hill; Digging Up History

body: From Griselda's in Park Slope to Trixie Glamourama in East New York and Vinny Venditti's in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn has plenty of beauty salons. It also has plenty of health clubs. But what the borough doesn't have is a spa that is open seven days a week and uses organic products. Debra Ann Townes and Yvonne Bernard plan to open the upscale,
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: COBBLE HILL; Body Coddling a la Mode
